title: Theorizing Iberia
description: In recent years, the term “Iberian Studies” has emerged conjointly with a number of proposals to reconceptualize the field of peninsular literary and cultural studies. Generally speaking, these proposals call for a shift away from the monolingual, nation-based canons of “Spanish” and “Portuguese” literature and toward a comparative approach that places Spanish and Portuguese literatures in dialogue with each other and with Catalan, Galician, Basque, and other peninsular traditions. While this development responds in part to contemporary trends in literary studies and to cultural and political realities in the Iberian Peninsula today, it also draws on the historical precedent of Iberianism, a movement that involved a number of Iberian intellectuals and artists in the last half of the nineteenth century and the first decades of the twentieth. In this course we analyze primary works from this historical period alongside some of the most recent interventions in the Iberian Studies debate. Primary readings include works by Antero de Quental, Oliveira Martins, Rosalía de Castro, Emilia Pardo Bazán, Miguel de Unamuno, Joan Maragall, Enric Prat de la Riba, and Miguel Torga, among others. Secondary texts include work by Joan Ramon Resina, César Domínguez, Joseba Gabilondo, Kirsty Hooper, Mario Santana, Robert Patrick Newcomb, Roberta Johnson, and Silvia Bermúdez. Texts are provided in the original language, and in translation when appropriate. Seminar discussion takes place in Spanish or Portuguese, depending on the linguistic abilities of each student. Students may submit written work in Spanish or Portuguese.
